attributes.title: The Short and Long-Term Effects of Violence and Repression: A Series of Survey Experiments in Ukraine

q1.value: The Short and Long-Term Effects of Violence and Repression: A Series of Survey Experiments in Ukraine

q2.value: Thomas Zeitzoff | Alexander Kupatadze | Yuri Zhukov

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We investigate three interrelated phenomena surrounding conflict as it related to the ongoing and historical violence in Ukraine, and in particular Eastern Ukraine: 1) the effect of political violence on attitudes towards corruption and extrajudicial violence; 2) the susceptibility of conflict-exposed individuals to misinformation and conspiracy theories; and 3) the long-term effects of political violence on historical attitudes. To examine these three phenomena, we will conduct a survey experiment in three eastern provinces of Ukraine: Donetsk, Luhansk and Kharkiv. After protests in favor of a free trade agreement with the European Union escalated to a revolution in February 2014, Russia annexed Ukraine’s Crimea peninsula, and provided support to separatists in the heavily-industrialized Donbass region around Donetsk and Luhansk. The fighting in Donbass (April 2014-present), and unrest in Ukraine more broadly, has killed more than 10,000 people and displaced more than 1.6 million. Besides the humanitarian cost, the violence in Ukraine has facilitated an increase in smuggling, and fed concerns about growing organized crime presence in conflict-affected regions. To boost the public’s confidence in the state, the Ukrainian government has launched police reforms and a host of other measures to address corruption, with mixed success. These regions also experienced disparate impact from the Holodomor/Great Famine of the 1930s and Soviet and Nazi era repression in the lead up and during WWII.

q16.value: The goal of our project is to explore how violence affects three interrelated phenomena 1) How violence influences attitudes towards corruption and extrajudicial violence We believe exposure to violence will increase support and tolerance of corruption, as well as boosting support for for both harsh military violence, as well as extrajudicial punishment. We also believe that those lower in institutional trust will be more in favor of extrajudicial violence, and tolerant of corruption. 2) The susceptibility of conflict-exposed individuals to misinformation We believe that those exposed to violence will be more likely to believe in conspiracy theories and misinformation, though we think this relationship will be contingent on the ideology of the individual and the conspiracy theory (pro/vs. anti- Russian/Ukrainian). 3) The long-term effects of political violence. We believe that exposure to long-term violence and repression (Holodomor and WWII), will lead to lower trust in institutions, favor informal institutions, and be more tolerant of corruption. We also believe that present-day Ukrainian/Russian attitudes will be correlated with beliefs on historical attitudes. Additional, predictions are found in our attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Using a survey and survey experiment of ~1,200 individuals in Eastern Ukraine, we will manipulate the salience of corruption or wartime violence. We will then measure how this influences attitudes towards corruption, organized crime, attitudes towards the state/legal system, misinformation, and historical attitudes related to USSR/Ukrainian nationalism. We will match this up with observational as well as surveyed exposure to present-day violence and crime, historical violence, and familial political attitudes.

q27.value: Kyiv International Institute of Sociology (Survey Firm)

attributes.title: Social polarization in the Czech Republic

q1.value: Social polarization in the Czech Republic

q2.value: Lenka Hrbková | Petr Voda | Vlastimil Havlík

q5.value: The study is funded by the Czech Science Foundation, grant no. GA17-09296S.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We propose an exploratory study of polarization in the Czech Republic, the main aim of the study is to test whether there is any significant polarizing element in the current Czech society which would contribute to negative mutual relationships among public. The study follows a relational concept of polarization, which has been previously understood as affective polarization between partisans in US politics (Iyengar, Sood, & Lelkes, 2012; Westwood et al., 2018) or a more general hostility based on simplification of complex social relations into a dominant antagonistic conflict defining society in terms of “Us” vs. “Them” (McCoy, Rahman, & Somer, 2018; McCoy & Somer, 2019). Polarization influences non-political domains of people’s lives (). and weakens discursive norms of democratic deliberation (Strickler, 2018). Even though there has been discussion about increasing tensions among Czech public, we do not know which factors actually play role in possible affective polarization (in terms of negative affect towards other people in society) or antagonization of social relations in the context of the Czech Republic. The main RQ: What factors contribute to negative mutual relationship among public in the Czech Republic? The main hypothetical sources of polarization in the study are: 1) Political partisanship – as assumed by the research on polarization in the US (Iyengar, Sood, & Lelkes, 2012; Westwood et al., 2018) 2) Attitudes about immigration – as assumed by the research on new political cleavage in European politics (Hooghe & Marks, 2018) 3) Values – authoritarian and libertarian values are assumed to cause so call cultural backlash and thus contribute to political conflict and hostility (Norris and Inglehart, 2019). 4) Frequency of talking about politics – which might be, according to recent study by Klar, Krupnikov, abd Ryan (2018), the actual force driving negative affect towards partisans in the US.

q16.value: H1: Partisanship will significantly influence people’s preferences. Individuals will prefer to talk to people who match a liked political party and reject those who match a disliked party, all else constant. H2: Attitudes to immigration will significantly influence people’s preference. Individuals will prefer to talk to people with a similar attitude to immigration and reject those with a different attitude, all else constant. H3: Individuals will prefer less to talk to other people who like to talk about politics more frequently, all else constant. H3a: Individuals will prefer to talk less to other people who like to talk about politics and vote for individual’s disliked parties compared to voters of liked parties. H3b: Individuals will prefer to talk less to other people with different attitudes on immigration who like to talk about politics compared to those with similar attitudes on immigration. H4: Polarization is driven neither by partisanship nor attitudes but by a more fundamental concept of values. Individuals will prefer to talk less to people with different values.

q17.value: The study is based on a conjoint experiment. In the experiment respondents will be asked to choose between two different people the one they would prefer to talk to. They will also rate the two people on feeling thermometers. The experimental task is repeated five times. The two personalities in the experimental task will be described by six attributes: Table 1. Conjoint attributes Gender 1. Male 2. Female Education 1. Elementary 2. Vocational school 3. High school 4. College Talks about politics 1. Often 2. Sometimes 3. Almost never What is important in life 1. Behaving properly, avoiding doing anything that people would say is wrong 2. Living in secure surroundings. Avoiding anything that might be dangerous 3. Likes surprises and always looks for new things 4. Thinking up new ideas and being creative Party vote 1. ANO 2. ODS 3. Piráti 4. ČSSD 5. KSČM 6. KDU-ČSL 7. TOP09 8. STAN 9. SPD 10 No party Immigration 1. Immigration makes our country a worse place to live 2. Immigration has no impact on the quality of life in our county 3. Immigration makes our country a better place to live The data will be collected by the marketing and research company Focus, based in Brno, the Czech Republic. The aimed sample is n = 1,000. The sample will be a non-probability sample (quotas on gender, education, age, region, size of municipality). Representative of the Czech population. Two different outcome variables are: a discrete choice between two personalities and rating of these personalities on feeling thermometers. The outcome variables will be analyzed using logistic regression and OLS respectively. First, the outcome variables will be regressed on the profile attributes as they are presented in the experiment – with the exception of party vote which will be recoded according to evaluation of the party by participants in a pre-test (liked/disliked). The regression models will also add interaction terms party vote * talk about politics and immigration attitude * talk about politics. Second, the variables will be matched to respondents demographics and attitudes indicated in the pre-test. Effects of correspondence of evaluated personalities attributes with respondents’ own characteristics will be tested via OSL (thermometer outcome) and logit (discrete choice) models.

attributes.title: Information About Constitutional Law & Public Opinion: An Experiment in Turkey

q1.value: Information About Constitutional Law & Public Opinion: An Experiment in Turkey

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: We are researching how information about whether an action taken by the government is constitutional changes public support for that action. There have been a number of similar papers testing this idea for information on international law, but less attention has been paid to the effect of constitutional law. Moreover, most the prior studies have been conducted in the United States. We intentionally sought to conduct our survey in a country with recent issues of rights violations, and to ask about a real event instead of a hypothetical scenario.

q16.value: The hypothesis we are testing is whether being told that a recent decision to ban wikipedia is constitutional or not changes levels of support for the decision. We are also testing several conditional effects. Specifically, will test whether the treatment effects changed based on the respondents’: (1) knowledge of constitutional law, (2) political ideology, (3) previous use of Wikipedia, (4) knowledge of political events; and (5) religious participation.

q17.value: The core of the experiment is reading the respondents information on the recent decision to ban wikipedia. The respondents are then sorted into groups that are provided different information on the constitutionality of that decision. We then will test the difference in levels of support for the decision to block wikipedia (and several other questions) between the five treatment groups.

registration_responses.q1: Information About Constitutional Law & Public Opinion: An Experiment in Turkey

attributes.title: The Role of Canvassing During the German Federal Election Campaign in 2017: Evidence From an Expert Survey

q1.value: The Role of Canvassing During the German Federal Election Campaign in 2017: Evidence From an Expert Survey

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: We conduct an expert survey with political actors in Germany. For this purpose, we will send an invitation to participate in an online survey to all outgoing members of the German parliament (Bundestag) and up to seven of their staffers. Furthermore, we will also send this survey to all candidates for parliament of the four currently represented parties in one of the 16 German states.

q16.value: We will test whether beliefs about the effectiveness of canvassing are in line with the actual effectiveness of canvassing.

attributes.title: Effectively Reducing the Political Appeal of Populism: A Survey Experiment

q1.value: Effectively Reducing the Political Appeal of Populism: A Survey Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: To what extent are mainstream parties' campaign messages able to persuade voters who have turned their back on these parties and now lean towards populist parties and politicians instead? Previous research has largely focused on the average voter, on mainstream partisans or on non-partisan voters (e.g. Arceneaux and Kolodny 2009; Brady and Johnston 2006; Gerber et al. 2011; Johnston et al. 2004). So we know little about the extent to which previous findings extend to the group of potentially alienated voters who distrust mainstream political elites and thus, are less likely to be responsive to mainstream campaign appeals (cf. Cramer 2016). Yet, persuading at least some of these voters seems increasingly crucial for parties and politicians across Western democracies in order to win elections. The present research project aims to address this question by conducting a survey experiment in the context of the 2017 German federal election. Focusing on a large sample of potentially alienated German voters, it tests the effectiveness of different campaign messages (priming of the economy, priming of change/strategic voting, priming of uncertainty/leadership characteristics and priming of policy considerations) and thus, sheds light on which messages are likely to work with this group of voters and which are not.

q16.value: H1: Priming of the good economic situation in Germany makes potentially alienated voters a) less likely to vote for the right-wing populist Alternative for Germany (AfD) b) more likely to vote for the Christian-Democratic Union/Christian-Social Union (CDU/CSU) (i.e. party of incumbent chancellor) H2: Informing potentially alienated voters about their strategic options of how to reduce the electoral chances of a future grand coalition will make them a) less likely to vote for the right-wing populist AfD b) more likely to vote for the Free Democratic Party (FDP) and/or the Greens (i.e. potential CDU/CSU coalition partners outside of a grand coalition) H3: Priming of political uncertainty and leadership characteristics makes potentially alienated voters a) less likely to vote for the right-wing populist AfD b) more likely to vote for the CDU/CSU (i.e. party of incumbent chancellor) H4: Priming of social inequality and information about the main left-wing party’s policy positions and their main competitors’ positions on this issue make potentially alienated voters a) less likely to vote for the right-wing populist AfD b) more likely to vote for the SPD (i.e. main left-wing party strongly supporting redistributive policies) H5: The effect of priming the good economic situation in Germany on the vote intention for the incumbent (i.e. for the CDU/CSU; H1b) is a) smaller for AfD supporters (economic voting < cultural threat) than for non-AfD supporters b) larger for AfD supporters (economic voting > cultural threat) than for non-AfD supporters H6: The effect of priming a strategic vote choice against the incumbent grand coalition and in favor of the FDP and/or Greens (H2b) is a) smaller for AfD supporters (change < protest) than for non-AfD supporters b) larger for AfD supporters (change > protest) than for non-AfD supporters H7: The effect of priming political uncertainty and leadership characteristics on the vote intention for the CDU/CSU (H3b) is a) smaller for AfD supporters (insecurity < distrust) than for non-AfD supporters b) larger for AfD supporters (insecurity > distrust) than for non-AfD supporters H8: The effect of priming social inequality and providing information about parties’ policy positions on the vote intention for the SPD (H4b) is a) smaller for AfD supporters (social inequality < cultural threat) than for non-AfD supporters b) larger for AfD supporters (social inequality > cultural threat) than for non-AfD supporters All these hypotheses will be tested with a second set of dependent variables: respondents' favorability ratings of political parties.

q17.value: We use a sample of approximately 1,750 respondents who are randomly drawn from among the most anti-immigrant (measured with the standard item from the German Longitudinal Election Study (GLES)) 35% to 40% of voting-eligible citizens in YouGov Deutschland's online panel. YouGov randomly assigns respondents to one of the four treatment groups or to the control group and administers the survey about two weeks before the election. Respondents in the treatment groups receive one of four different potential campaign messages that prime the economy, strategic considerations, uncertainty/leadership characteristics or social inequality. Key outcome variables are respondents' self-reported vote intention and their party ratings. We will use OLS with covariate adjustment and robust standard errors for the analysis of treatment effects.

registration_responses.q1: Effectively Reducing the Political Appeal of Populism: A Survey Experiment
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

attributes.title: Riots, Ethnic Cooperation and Religious Fundamentalism

q1.value: Riots, Ethnic Cooperation and Religious Fundamentalism

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Do inter-ethnic clashes affect inter- and intra-ethnic cooperation? And does such violence spur religious fundamentalism? We approach these questions by studying the 2010 inter-ethnic clashes in Southern Kyrgyzstan. Following the toppling of Kyrgyzstan’s long-term president Bakiyev in April 2010, protests broke out throughout the country. In Osh, a city almost equally split between Kyrgyz and Uzbek residents, these protests quickly assumed an ethnic dimension and turned into violent clashes, which left at least 400 people dead. The vast majority of the attacks were perpetrated by ethnic Kyrgyz against ethnic Uzbeks. To neutral observers, the scale of the outburst of violence came as a surprise. Only when the security forces intervened three days later could the violence be stopped. The present project studies the aftermath of the clashes, roughly seven years later. In this pre-analysis plan, we lay out the analyses we plan to conduct, honing in on our sampling, measurement and estimation strategy.

q16.value: - The Osh inter-ethnic clashes increased in-group cooperation among victimized individuals as compared to non-victimized individuals. - The Osh inter-ethnic clashes increased out-group cooperation among victimized individuals as compared to non-victimized individuals. - The Osh inter-ethnic clashes increased religious fundamentalism among victimized individuals as compared to non-victimized individuals.

q17.value: We compare survey data from victimized and non-victimized areas.

registration_responses.q1: Riots, Ethnic Cooperation and Religious Fundamentalism

attributes.title: Information Diffusion and the Formation of Political Opinions

q1.value: Information Diffusion and the Formation of Political Opinions

q2.value: Skyler Cranmer | Robert Bond | Eloise Kaizar | David Sivakoff | Elias Assaf | Lauren Ratliff Santoro

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The aim of the project is to learn about knowledge and opinion formation and alteration as a result of official information and peer opinion. As described in detail in the protocol, participants are recruited from existing student groups, such that each experimental session includes at least 10 participants. Each participant selects three ‘friends.’ Participants are asked demographic questions before the experiment begins, and knowledge and opinion questions in each of 10 rounds, as outlined in the protocol. Between each round of questions, participants are exposed to some piece of information and the opinions/answers of their friends. The initial resulting data frame for each group has one row per participant that contains the answers to all the questions, as well as their choice of friends.

q16.value: We plan to formally explore many questions with this data. These include: 1. Do participants change the answers to the questions over time? 2. Are participants whose friends have positive (or negative) opinions more likely to choose a positive (or negative) opinion in the following round? 3. Are participants whose friends have answered correctly (or incorrectly) more likely to answer correctly (or incorrectly) in the following round? 4. Are participants who have seen positive (or negative) official information more likely to choose a positive (or negative) opinion in following rounds? 5. Are participants who have seen correct(or incorrect) answer more likely to answer correctly (or incorrectly) in following rounds? 6. For questions 2-4, if there is an effect of friends’ responses, is the effect linear? 7. Do participants who have seen official information respond to opinion questions differ- ently from those who have not? 8. Do participants who have seen official information answer knowledge questions cor- rectly more often than those who have not? 9. Is access to official information associated with the opinions or answers of participants two steps away? 10. For questions 6-7, does any effect of official information diminish over time? 11. For questions 2-4, is any effect of friends’ answers moderated by availability of official information? 12. For cases where there are both friend and information effects, which effect is stronger? 13. Do structural features of the network moderate any effects of friends’ opinions or official information? For example, does a friends’ centrality or out-degree moderate any friend effect? 14. Does the order in which friends appear in the selection list moderate any friend effect? 15. Are any effects of friends and official information different for opinion questions than for knowledge questions? 16. Do network-level outcomes, such as the proportion of participants who answer correctly or have a positive opinion, differ by experimental factor, such as the proportion of participants who received official information in the first round? 17. What are the natural occurrences of network structure within an experiment, and are these frequencies related to group-level variables?

q17.value: Our primary analysis will answer questions 1-12 via question-specific models that account for both correlation across time and correlation within network. These models, described in our attached plan, are based on the Markov property, where an individual’s answer is independent of all other answers given their previous answer and their friends’ answers. Secondary analysis will also explore more advanced models. In particular, we plan to implement latent factor models that capture patterns across similar questions. The remainder of the questions are considered exploratory in the sense that we do not consider them in the decision to continue collecting data, and do not intend to adjust for multiplicity in the analysis. All model-based analyses will rely on a Bayesian approach, but for some analyses we also intend to employ permutation-based testing and simple descriptive statistics.

attributes.title: Extremist Militant Groups and the Provision of Justice: Experimental Evidence from South Central Somalia

q1.value: Extremist Militant Groups and the Provision of Justice: Experimental Evidence from South Central Somalia

q5.value: We thank The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) Crime and Violence Initiative for funding support. We also gratefully acknowledge the support of United Nations Women, the United Nations Assistance Mission in Somalia (UNSOM),, the Rule of Law and Security Institutions Group (ROLSIG), and the Somali Ministry of Justice. This project would not be possible without Virginie Blanchard. Jeda Ahmed and Rashid Abdi provided excellent research assistance., We have received valuable comments from Richard Nielsen, Cyrus Samii, and workshop participants at NYU and WESSI-Beirut.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan (PAP) outlines our primary hypotheses to be tested and the empirical specifications to be used for a conjoint experiment conducted across 40 districts with over 600 subjects in South Central Somalia, an area of active conflict. We aim to evaluate what leads individuals to seek adjudication of disputes by al-Shabaab, a central obstacle to the establishment of the rule of law, and not formal courts or traditional elders. The conjoint experiment was conducted with local citizens (non-leaders) from July to September 2018 but data entry is not complete and thus data has not yet been conveyed in its final form to the researchers.

q16.value: In our PAP, we propose a number of hypotheses as to how vignette attributes, respondent demographic characteristics, and district-level data (such as exposure to violence or the degree to which a district is under the control of al-Shabaab) might affect forum choice. We have two sets of outcomes: subjects are asked to choose whether they would take a hypothetical case to al-Shabaab versus the formal court, or to al-Shabaab versus traditional authorities.

q17.value: We conduct a conjoint experiment to test our hypotheses. We supplement this data with survey and other available data, as specified in our PAP. We also hope to conduct focus group discussions to better evaluate mechanisms for identified effects.

q27.value: Researchers supervised the implementation of the experiment, as detailed in the PAP. Enumerators contracted by the United Nations and by the researchers conducted the experiment.

This project would not be possible without Virginie Blanchard. Jeda Ahmed and Rashid Abdi provided excellent research assistance., We have received valuable comments from Richard Nielsen, Cyrus Samii, and workshop participants at NYU and WESSI-Beirut.

attributes.title: Domestic Losers, Foreign Winners? Support for Climate Action under Weak International Institutions

q1.value: Domestic Losers, Foreign Winners? Support for Climate Action under Weak International Institutions

q5.value: We want to thank Michaël Aklin, Robert Johns, and Matto Mildenberger for useful comments on previous versions of the questionnaire. Funding from the University of Essex is gratefully acknowledged.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This document provides a brief pre-analysis plan for a survey experiment for a paper provisionally titled ``Domestic Losers, Foreign Winners? Support for Climate Action under Weak International Institutions.'' The main goal of the experiment it to understand how different information about winning and losing sectors in the UK and Germany affect support for ambitious climate action among UK respondents. The survey will be fielded to a sample of (initially) 400 respondents through Amazon MTurk end of May 2019. The survey experiment features five experimental conditions, one control group and four experimental groups. Assignment to group is random. The control group is provided with basic information about the UK's climate action commitments under the 2015 Paris Agreement as well as associated costs and benefits. All respondents receive this information. The four treatment conditions provide information about winning and losing sectors in the UK and Germany. Specifically, the ``domestic winners'' (T1) treatment highlights benefits from climate action for the UK energy sector; the ``domestic losers'' (T2) treatment emphasizes losses for the UK transportation sector; the ``foreign winners'' (T3) treatment points out benefits for the German transportation section; the ``foreign losers'' treatment (T4) sector highlights losses for the German fossil fuel energy sector.

q16.value: We formulate several baseline expectations about the treatment effects in our survey experiment. (1) We expect support for ambitious climate action to be fairly low in the control group across all outcomes, but particularly so for UK climate action. (2) Relative to the control group, we expect support for UK climate action to be higher for respondents who received the UK winners treatment (T1); we expect it to be lower for those who received the UK losers treatment (T2). Effects for respondents receiving the foreign winners (T3) and foreign losers (T4) treatment should be smaller in size, possibly indistinguishable from the control group mean for UK climate action. (3) We expect support for German climate action to be higher for the foreign winners treatment (T3) and smaller for the German losers treatment (T4) relative to the control group.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using simple, two-tailed difference-in-means with appropriate multiple comparisons adjustments. For our conditional hypotheses we use parametric regression models.
